systems.name: ZX Spectrum 48kb
systems.desc: The ZX Spectrum was among the decade’s best-selling computers, captivating millions via its iconic rubber keys and vibrant gaming library. 16kb or 48kb, color

systems.name: Spectrum 128
systems.desc: The ZX Spectrum 128, released in 1985–86, expanded RAM to 128 KB and Spectrum+ keyboard.

systems.name: Microdigital TK90X
systems.desc: The Microdigital TK90X is a Brazilian clone of the Sinclair ZX Spectrum. It uses a Z80A CPU, offers 16–48KB RAM, BASIC ROM, CMOS graphics, and TV output.

systems.name: Microdigital TK95
systems.desc: The Microdigital TK95 is an evolution of the TK90X with an enhanced mechanical keyboard, Z80A CPU, 48 KB RAM, 16 KB ROM, composite video output, and built-in joystick ports, housed in a plastic case.

systems.name: PET
systems.desc: The VIC-20 featured a 1.1 MHz MOS 6502 CPU, 5 KB RAM, 176×184 graphics, and cartridge-based storage

systems.name: VIC 20
systems.desc: The VIC-20 featured a 1.1 MHz MOS 6502 CPU, 5 KB RAM, 176×184 graphics, and cartridge-based storage

systems.name: Commodore 64
systems.desc: Commodore 64 featured a MOS 6510 CPU at 1 MHz, 64 KB RAM, and the iconic SID sound chip.

systems.name: Commodore 128
systems.desc: Commodore 128 offered dual CPUs (8502 at 2 MHz, Z80 at 4 MHz), 128 KB RAM, and three modes.

systems.name: Hotbit 1.2
systems.desc: Brazilian MSX 1.2

systems.name: Expert 1.1
systems.desc: Brazilian MSX 1

systems.name: VG8000
systems.desc: Philips MSX 1.0

systems.name: FS-5500 F2
systems.desc: National FS-5500 F2 MSX2

systems.name: FS-A1WSX
systems.desc: Panasonic MSX2+

systems.name: Boosted MSX2
systems.desc: 2048Kb, V9958, SCC+, FMPAC, MSX Audio, MoonSound, GFX9000, 512Kb RAM, Basic Compiler

systems.name: Boosted MSX2+ JP
systems.desc: Kanji ROM, MSX-MUSIC, 2048 Kb, V9958, SCC+, MSX Audio, MoonSound, GFX9000, 512Kb RAM, Basic Compiler

systems.name: Boosted Turbo-R
systems.desc: R800, Kanji ROM, MSX-Music, PCM, MSX-MIDI, 2048 kb Mapper, V9958, SCC+, MSX Audio, MoonSound, GFX9000, %12Kb MegaRAM, Basic compiler, IDE Interface with 100Mb HD and CD-ROM

systems.name: Nextor IDE Expert 3
systems.desc: Custom MSX2+ with Nextor IDE and hard Disk

systems.name: FS-A1GT
systems.desc: Panasonic MSX Turbo R

systems.name: Amiga 1000 (Workbench 1.1)
systems.desc: 1985 Commodore Amiga 1000 shipped with a Motorola 68000 CPU at 7.16 MHz, 256 KB RAM, and the custom OCS chipset.

systems.name: ZX81 - 9
systems.desc: The Sinclair ZX81 revolutionized home computing in 1981, offering affordable programming, minimal graphics, and inspiring a hobbyist community, sparking innovation

systems.name: Cambridge Z88
systems.desc: The Cambridge Z88, launched in 1987, pioneered portable computing with battery efficiency, integrated software suite, and compact design for professionals.

systems.name: Sinclair QL
systems.desc: The Sinclair QL was an affordable business microcomputer with a Motorola 68008 CPU and innovative microdrive storage

systems.name: Sam Coupe
systems.desc: The Sam Coupé was an 8-bit microcomputer manufactured by Miles Gordon Technology in 1989, featuring advanced graphics, stereo sound, microdrives.

systems.name: ZX Uno
systems.desc: The ZX-Uno is an FPGA-based ZX Spectrum clone, crowdfunded in 2016, featuring SD card storage, PS/2 keyboard, composite video, audio.

systems.name: ZX Spectrum NEXT
systems.desc: The ZX Spectrum Next is an FPGA-based developed by Victor Truco and launched in 2017 offering Z80 at 28 MHz, 2 MB RAM, HDMI, SD storage.

systems.name: CPC 464
systems.desc: The Amstrad CPC 464 launched in 1984 with integrated cassette drive, 64 KB RAM, vibrant graphics, BASIC, and affordable home computing

systems.name: PCW 8256
systems.desc: Launched in 1985, 256Kb RAM, disk drive and included printer, targeting office market with word-processor integrated

systems.name: CPC 664
systems.desc: Launched in 1985 offered 64 KB RAM, built-in 3-inch floppy drive, sleek design, vivid graphics, and BASIC.

systems.name: CPC 6128
systems.desc: The Amstrad CPC 6128 released in 1985 featured 128 KB RAM, built-in 3-inch floppy disk, advanced BASIC, and vibrant display modes.

systems.name: Amiga 500
systems.desc: Commodore Amiga 500 featured a 7.16 MHz Motorola 68000, 512 KB RAM, and the Agnus, Denise, Paula custom chips.

systems.name: Amiga 500+
systems.desc: Commodore A500+ includes 1MB chip RAM, Kickstart 2.04, onboard clock port and PCMCIA slot, unlike A500’s 512KB and Kickstart 1.3.

systems.name: Amiga 600 HD
systems.desc: Commodore Amiga 600 features 1MB Chip RAM, onboard PCMCIA slot, compact design, Paula audio, limited expansion compared to original A500.

systems.name: Amiga 1200 HD
systems.desc: Commodore Amiga 1200 shipped with a 14 MHz Motorola 68EC020 CPU, 2 MB RAM, AGA chipset, and a PCMCIA slot.

systems.name: Amiga 4000 ClassicWB
systems.desc: Commodore Amiga 4000 delivered a 25 MHz Motorola 68040 CPU, 2 MB Fast RAM expandable, and the AGA chipset.

systems.name: Apple ][ Plus
systems.desc: Apple II Plus added Integer BASIC and 16–48 KB RAM support, offering color graphics and expansion slots, and became a major success.

systems.name: Apple //e
systems.desc: Apple IIe featured a 1 MHz 6502 CPU, 64 KB RAM (expandable to 128 KB), ProDOS support, durable keyboard.

systems.name: Performa System 7.5.5
systems.desc: The Macintosh Performa running System 7.5.5 delivers classic Mac OS features, multimedia performance, and intuitive, user-friendly computing in vintage style

systems.name: Macintosh 128 system 3.2
systems.desc: Macintosh 128K, released in 1984, achieved success with a Motorola 68000 CPU at 8 MHz, 128 KB RAM, 9-inch monochrome display, and GUI mouse interface.

systems.name: Macintosh 128 system 2.2
systems.desc: Macintosh 128K, released in 1984, achieved success with a Motorola 68000 CPU at 8 MHz, 128 KB RAM, 9-inch monochrome display, and GUI mouse interface.

systems.name: TRS-80 Model III
systems.desc: Released in 1980, used a Zilog Z80A at 2.03 MHz with 16–48 KB RAM and cassette storage.

systems.name: TRS Color Computer 2
systems.desc: The TRS-80 Color Computer 2 featured a Motorola 6809E at 0.895 MHz, 16–64 KB RAM, and 256×192 graphics.

systems.name: Prologica CP-500
systems.desc: Introduced in 1982 by Prológica as a Brazilian clone of the TRS-80 Model III, the CP-500 ran a Zilog Z80A at 2 MHz with 16–48 KiB RAM and used floppy-disk storage.

systems.name: Atari 800
systems.desc: Atari 800 offered a 1.79 MHz MOS 6502, expandable 8–48 KB RAM, and 320×192 high-resolution graphics

systems.name: Atari 1200XL
systems.desc: Atari 800XL featured a 1.79 MHz MOS 6502C CPU, 64 KB RAM, and 320×192 graphics.

systems.name: Atari 520ST TOS 1.04
systems.desc: Atari 520ST ran a Motorola 68000 CPU at 8 MHz with 1024 KiB RAM, 320×200 color graphics; floppy-disk storage.

systems.name: Atari STE 1Mb TOS 2.06
systems.desc: 1989 improved version of Atari ST, with better graphics and multimedia hardware and operating system

systems.name: Falcon 030 HD
systems.desc: Introduced in 1992, Atari’s Falcon 030 ran a Motorola 68030 at 16 MHz with 1 MB RAM (expandable), onboard DSP, MIDI ports, and SVGA graphics.

systems.name: Texas TI-99/4A
systems.desc: Texas Instruments TI-99/4A: early 1980s home computer with 16-bit CPU, color graphics, speech, and cartridge-based software.

systems.name: Spectravideo SV-318
systems.desc: Spectravideo 318 is an early 8-bit home computer, not MSX compatible, with z80 CPU and BASIC interpreter from Microsoft

systems.name: Jupiter Ace
systems.desc: Jupiter Ace was a British 8-bit home computer, running FORTH instead of BASIC, using Z80 CPU

systems.name: TRS Color Computer 1.0 32Kb
systems.desc: The TRS-80 Color Computer (CoCo) was a Tandy home computer using the Motorola 6809 CPU with color graphics.

systems.name: Prologica CP-400 DOS
systems.desc: The CP-400 was Prologica’s response to Brazil’s market restrictions, replicating the TRS-80 Color Computer with full software compatibility.

systems.name: Dragon 32
systems.desc: Dragon 32, British TRS-80 CoCo clone. Motorola 6809 CPU, 32KB RAM, compatible with CoCo software, cassette and cartridge support.

systems.name: Dragon 64
systems.desc: Dragon 64, enhanced British CoCo-compatible system. Motorola 6809 CPU, 64KB RAM, RS-232 port, identical software compatibility with Dragon 32.

systems.name: IBM-PC windows 3.1
systems.desc: Major redesign with Program Manager, File Manager, 16 color VGA support, enhanced multitasking and broad software developer adoption

systems.name: IBM-PC Windows 1.04
systems.desc: First GUI for IBM PCs, offering tiled windows, mouse support and basic applications like notepad, calculator and paint

systems.name: IBM-PC VGA windows 2.0
systems.desc: Introduced overlapping windows, improved memory management, desktop icons and better application support, including Excel and Word integration

systems.name: IBM-PC VGA Windows 95 OSR2
systems.desc: Windows 95 OSR2 improved stability added FAT32 support, better hardware drives, USB and networkin for home users

systems.name: xterm
systems.desc: XWindow Terminal Emulator

systems.desc: Raspberry pi config tools
